p: Whether early childhood viral infection initiates a series of events that lead to asthma has been an area of much interest and study. One analysis showed that infants reaching 4 months of age at the winter virus peak had a 29% increased risk of developing later asthma compared with those reaching age 1 year at the winter peak ( 21). If viruses do initiate asthma in some patients, then prevention of RSV or HRV or a similar illness in a critical time period might prevent or reduce the frequency of asthma in later years. Nonatopic infants who had received palivizumab (a humanized MAb against RSV) for prevention of RSV infection showed an 80% reduction in risk of recurrent wheezing from ages 2 to 5 ( 22), though no effect was noted in atopic children.
